newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Wharf interim profits as expected, better H2 seen.
newsitem.headline: Wharf interim profits as expected, better H2 seen.

text.p: Wharf Holdings Ltd's interim earnings announced on Wednesday came in within the range of expectations and analysts expected to see an improvement in second-half figures compared to the first half.

The Hong Kong conglomerate reported first-half profit of HK$1.30 billion (US$168 million), down from HK$3.00 billion in the first half of last year when the figures were boosted by a HK$1.95 billion exceptional gain.
Operating profit in the first half 1996 rose 37 percent to HK$1.33 billion from HK$970.2 million.
"I think they (the results) are really close," said Philip Tulk, analyst at DBS Securities.
Analysts said first-half growth in rental income and property sales had been disappointing but they expected an improvement in the second half.
"Investment rental income was up about seven percent. I had expected more growth," said one analyst at a Japanese brokerage.
"Gains on the sale of property were lower than what I was going for," he added.
The analyst said he had expected interim profit of HK$1.4 billion but said "most people are probably comfortable with the general results".
"I think the second half will definitely be better. They sold some property but it will not be booked until the second half," the analyst said.

Wharf said property sales activities had been revived "but only a small portion of the profits arising was booked in the first half of 1996". It said four floors of Telford House had been sold recently and more sales were envisaged.

Franklin Lam, director of research at HG Asia, said the results also fell short of his forecast of HK$1.46 billion profit due to bigger-than-anticipated losses at cable television arm Wharf Cable and losses linked to the New T&T telephone unit.
But he said he was maintaining Wharf as a "top tier buy".

"I think all the core rentals, MTL (container terminal operator Modern Terminals Ltd) and all other operations including property sales and so on are all in line," he said. "The company is improving. We have touched a bottom."
Lam said Wharf posted a loss of HK$300 million for cable television in the first half which was higher than his estimate.
"Last year they made HK$600 million in losses on cable TV. We were expecting HK$450 million for the full year," he said.
Wharf said its financial performance was also hurt in the first half by "budgeted start-up deficits at New T&T."
"We were expecting them to continue to capitalise on losses but they declared a loss and allowed it to flow through to the bottom line," said Lam.
"The second half will be an improvement on the first half in all aspects," he said. "I think the bulk of the reversions on the rentals will come through in the second half."
Tulk, who had forecast profit of HK$1.2 billion, said Wharf had booked a larger gain than he had anticipated from the sale of its Omni Hotels interest and certain investment properties.
Wharf reported an exceptional gain of HK$102.7 million in the period.

He said cable losses were also lower than his HK$350 million forecast. "Reduction of losses at cable help forward growth," said Tulk, adding that he may lift his full year estimate to HK$3.0 billion from HK$2.9 billion.
"It's a good set of figures. The bar was set quite low and they jumped over it," he said.
